issue.title: More Info on Ignored tests
issue.body: When using the [Ignore] - attribute, is it possible for NUnit to obtain sourcefilename and linenumber and output this info in the result-report?

body:
Tyrel asks:

"Can we specify a compile Error or warning when the date is in the past? If so do you know where I can learn about it? I am very interested in learning about how to do something like that if it can be done."

I initially thought this could be done, but apparently it is not so easy. We'll need to do some research into it.

Barring a compiler warning, we can do a number of things once the enddate has passed:
1. Simply run the test (Ignore the Ignore).
2. Ignore the test with a different message - hoping someone reads it.
3. Mark the test as nonrunnable, which gives an error that has to be fixed by removing or changing the date.

Charlie
1) or 3) make sense to me.  I was just about to attempt to create the feature but quickly realized it would involve some changes to the framework or an addin.

Yes, it would have to be implemented as a modification to IgnoreAttribute.
It's a relatively easy fix.

Charlie

On Thu, Dec 19, 2013 at 1:59 PM, Andrew Ochsner notifications@github.comwrote:

> 1) or 3) make sense to me. I was just about to attempt to create the
> feature but quickly realized it would involve some changes to the framework
> or an addin.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/nunit/nunit-framework/issues/45#issuecomment-30970595
> .

Wanted to take a stab at this but struggling a bit to figure out the right way to parse the future date.  Thought maybe I could just assume it's in the same culture (for US, "10/1/2000" would be Oct 1st).  But in the world of global development, I'm not sure I can make this assumption (e.g. code base shared between US & Europe where the previous string would mean Jan 10th).  

Think I just need to use ISO 8601 (2000-10-1)

Concerning behaviour of a IgnoreUntil-Attribute, we have used it some years ago in the way, that we have examined the attribute using an addin. If the ignore-until-date has been in the past, the addin has simply removed the attribute and the test has been executed, no matter if the result was "failed" or "passed", this is up to the test itself. I can remember that some of the guys have even requested to define a test-id or feature-id to the test and get the ignore-until-date from some external maintained file, that would have the information about when a certain feature should be finished with implementation, so that the test should no longer be ignored to that date. However this idea was never realized. Still i vote for to decouple test execution information (which i believe ignore-until belongs to) from the test itself. The test should not know when it will get executed, it should just know how to do the test. Test execution information on  a test does not really fulfill the SRP, the test should be responsable for how to test and the execution should be responsable about what test to execute when and some other thing should be responsable for the results of the execution of a test.
Why not use the DateTime class as argument for the IgnoreUntilDate information?

Regarding "separated metadata":

The metadata is already separated from the test by being placed in an
attribute. The code of a test normally is unaware of what metadata is
placed on it. Of course, you can find it by clever use of Reflection, but
this, in my view, would indeed break the SRP.

NUnit is pretty much designed around the use of attributes to identify and
qualify tests. Doing it another way means writing a new framework, which is
certainly possible.

On the other hand, any runner is able to make decisions about what to run
and in what order to run them.

Anyway, let's remove this broad discussion form the particular bug, since
it's a much larger architecture issue. If you'd like to discuss a new
paradigm for identifying tests, the nunit-discuss list is probably the best
place.

On Tue, Jan 7, 2014 at 6:04 AM, yetibrain notifications@github.com wrote:

> Concerning behaviour of a IgnoreUntil-Attribute, we have used it some
> years ago in the way, that we have examined the attribute using an addin
> regarding the date. If the ignore-until-date has been in the past, the
> addin has simply removed the attribute and the test has been executed, no
> matter if the result was "failed" or "passed", this is up to the test
> itself. I can remember that some of the guys have even requested to define
> a test-id or feature-id to the test and get the ignore-until-date from some
> external maintained file, that would have the information about when a
> certain feature should be finished with implementation, so that the test
> should no longer be ignored to that date. However this idea was never
> realized. Still i vote for to decouple test execution information (which i
> believe ignore-until belongs to) from the test itself. The test should not
> know when it will get executed, it should just know how to do the test.
> Test execution information on a test does not rea lly fulfill the SRP, the
> test should be responsable for how to test and the execution should be
> responsable about what test to execute when and some other thing should be
> responsable for the results of the execution of a test.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/nunit/nunit-framework/issues/45#issuecomment-31739248
> .

@CharliePoole 
It is absolutely ok to classify tests with certain attributes, especially categories make sense in my opinion. But every attribute that classifies "a test's current situation" doesn't belong to the sourcecode of the test (and the attributes are part of the source), it belongs to a pool regarding the tests history. Example: Test A ran every month in 2013 and was always "passed", just in month "8" it was "failed" due to a bug in the testee. So this is a history. Would it make sense to glue every testresult as a attribute in front of the test method?

@yetibrain: This issue is about ignoring a test until a certain date. In this case, the metadata does not record history at all. It records a decision made by the programmer, just the same as any IgnoreAttribute.

@aochsner: I'm working on another project for the moment but I'll review your changed pull request in the next few days.
